utterance.speaker: Warren
utterance.content: The risotto’s not bad, but it’s not what Chef Zane did back a Fortunato. He replaced the rosemary with saffron, for one thing. And what is this stock? Did he get it. out of a can.

utterance.speaker: Paula
utterance.content: My fish isn’t bad.

utterance.speaker: Warren
utterance.content: But it’s not great either, I’m sure. I warned you against the snapper.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: Do you think it’ll calm down?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: God, I hope so. That guy is a bit of a blowhard, though, isn’t he? The food’s not spicy at all. You can barely taste it.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: Mine’s pretty spicy. Try it.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: I don’t taste anything.

utterance.speaker: Warren
utterance.content: You been throwing rolls at me?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Uh… It wasn’t me.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: Uh, really. He didn’t.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: I’m sorry that someone would choose to behave that way. Really, I… Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Bloody tears could just mean subconjuctival hemorrhage. He sneezed too hard from a cold, which caused his lack of taste. House isn’t gonna care. Does “black tie optional” really mean black tie? Cause I don’t wanna rent…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s been a glitch with the wedding. And House will be interested.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: A glitch?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: A glitch?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The seizures stopped after the surgery, but he’s having trouble adjusting to a split brain.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: A glitch?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This is Dr. Taub. Tell him about shopping.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Uh, I go into a grocery store. Everything seems normal. I get to the checkout and there’s all these extra items in the cart. Stuff I didn’t put there. Stuff that I hate. My left hand hates me.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yeah. I think House’ll be interested.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Clang, clang, clang went the trolley. Ding, ding ding hmm hmm hmm. Just warning you — I’m in a good mood. And largely pain free. So I have no idea how things are going —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Alien hand syndrome.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Set off by a stroke? Or is there a pony in the backyard?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Split brain. Right hemisphere controls the left and —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is making life miserable. Non-logical thinkers often do.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Current issue isn’t the split brain. The surgery corrected —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re dissing the right hemisphere?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Most people who have this operation don’t even notice they’re missing anything. Left brain has language, arithmetic, rationality. Right brain is a mute loser.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Right brain is more aesthetically oriented. Has greater facial recognition. I couldn’t have been a plastic surgeon without it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. And where would junior high be without our ability to judge people on aesthetics?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right brain’s also more aware of the present moment, our place in the universe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s a universal daisy chain of peace and love that throws buns at people.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: His present symptoms could mean autoimmune disease, nasolacrimal tumor, an infection or just a cold.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good morning, sunshine. We got a brand new toy. You wanna play?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great. I love euphemisms. By euphemism I mean when you say something and it means something else. Begin eliminating. Search the home.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The, uh… Isn’t that like locking the barn door after the horse has put his face between your breasts for an hour and a half?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m your boss. You’re an employee.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I’m not normally into role-playing, but if you wanna…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: People who get close to you get hurt. That’s a fact. You’re also a valued doctor in this hospital. That’s another fact. From now on, we’re gonna focus on the second fact.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So this isn’t you freaking out over last night.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This isn’t an emotional decision. I’m just giving you the rules. You can either accept them or leave.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I slept with Cuddy. After she helped me detox from Vicodin. I’ve been clean for almost 24 hours now. Okay. Thought I’d mention it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wow. Wow. One for each.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s what she said. A ha ha ha.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How’s the pain?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s probably got some bruising…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. I get it. You’re a stud. This is serious, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I feel better than I did four hours ago. Four hours from now, I’ll feel better than this.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The other wow. You were sober. She was sober?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Clean and sober and hot.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wow. This is fantastic. How are you gonna screw it up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Several good options. Unfortunately I don’t think she’s gonna give me the pleasure. She left before I woke up, and five minutes ago she told me that I’m just an employee.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ha.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, either she’s actually in love with you and scared, or she realized last night was a gigantic mistake. You were needy and vulnerable. She was maternal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think she jumped me out of pity?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, I’m saying whatever’s going on you… need to talk to her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Does our patient freak you out a little?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If he’s two people, then we’re all two people, and we just don’t know it. What does that say about identity?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It says we’re making it up as we go along, which I find freeing. Wow, I haven’t been in a bathroom this size since my dorm in med school. Is that fungus?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It’s from the steam build-up.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What do you think of this ‘glitch’ with Chase and Cameron’s wedding?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It’s always a sad thing when sperm comes between people.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I hear the sperm is very good today. I mean the salmon.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Go away.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No other tables.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’d let your wife keep another man’s offspring on ice next to the frozen peas, just in case? That’s what this is about. She’s not ready to commit to me. She’s planning for failure.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Did you know that male fruit flies have toxic chemicals in their seminal fluid that inhibit the sperm of other males.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wilson says we need to talk.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We talked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I agree. This has clearly gotten past the talking stage.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Hi. Great. Did you find my MP3?

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: Uh, not yet. But I got your shaving stuff, toothpaste, deodorant, some magazines and this cactus from your window.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: You didn’t have to do that, really. The hospital supplies all that stuff.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: I’m still trying too hard, huh? Trying to get your other half to like me.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: No, no, no, no. Don’t say that, okay? I like you. Which means that it — We shouldn’t read into that.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Antifungal meds. Ordinarily we’d put them in your IV but since your right brain doesn’t seem too fond of IVs… You should be feeling better in a few days.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: I have to get back to work. Rick says your shift will be waiting for you when you get back.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Thanks. Oh! Oh my God! God, I’m sorry. I’m so, so sorry. I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: I have to go. I have to get back to work.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Babe, wait. Hold on! No, it wasn’t me. I can’t walk.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Well, obviously it wasn’t the fungus.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: And it’s not a coordination issue. Dehydration can cause loss of balance. We haven’t had him on IV.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, good skin turgor. Not orthostatic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could be our tax dollars at work, constantly building new roadways and bridges. A meningioma. Slow growing. Could extend along the subosteal layer of the cranial cavity and be hidden by the bone.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The cancer cells are actually re-growing a connection between the left and right hemispheres.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If you’re right, the two halves have begun sending messages again, but it’s too early in the process for him to pick up on it. But, we can test for it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Proof.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You didn’t talk to her, did you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I talked, she’d have lied. I’d have lied. And though two negatives make a positive, I thought thermal-imaging photos seemed simpler. Note how many more heated areas appear after less than a minute with me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So it’s either love or possibly rage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t talk to her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I have no plans to talk to her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Manipulation is in your genetic code. You think I’m making a mistake, you move in to correct it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You are making a mistake.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She lied to me. Either last night or today. I need to find out which and why.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And clearly, thermal imaging is the way. This isn’t a case. You’re not looking for a diagnosis. If this matters at all to you, please, for once in your life, be an adult.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Keep your eyes focused on the plus sign. Any image that appears on the far right will only be seen by your left brain. And any image on your far left will only be seen by your right brain.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just start by saying the words.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Book. Giraffe. Willow. Fortunate.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re not saying the word.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: I didn’t see a word.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could you draw a picture of what you think the word might be.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Uh. Look. I didn’t see… Candle.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This is so cool.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s not freaky at all.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No communication.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So far.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Scott, why are you standing?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Uh… I’m a little chilly. I thought I’d get a sweater or something from my room. Is that okay?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A few more minutes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And that, ladies and gentlemen, is the left hemisphere… The side that’s obsessed with finding answers. The one that needs things to make sense. The interpreter. That’s where we tell the story of who we are and why we do things.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: That’s also the side that was wrong. Right brain's advantage is that it isn’t logical. Doesn’t choose which details to look at. Makes connections you could never see. You owe your insight to the “mute loser.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll send it tickets to a Phillies game.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Confabulation means no communication. Means your theory’s wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But he is cold. Why are you scratching?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: It itches.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ammonia breath. Your liver is failing.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I know for them to approve this price they’ll need statistical documentation. What? Why are you looking at me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: When you first walked in, I was under the impression you wanted to say something else.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Nope.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: About House and me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There’s nothing to talk about.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want permission to do a liver biopsy. We’re looking for sarcoidosis.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do you mean, fine?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What do you mean, what do I mean? Do you mean that because a liver biopsy is not a test that, by any stretch of the imagination, can be considered risky, so asking my permission is essentially wasting my time, and you’re wondering what my reaction to that will be?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are you trying to make me angry?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do your biopsy. And also do your clinic hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m blowing off my clinic hours.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Really? Let’s see how that goes. Still not angry. Try again later.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Uh, sorry. I know I’m a little ripe. Just a sweaty guy.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Recently?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Always. With a crazy left hand. Sometimes I fantasize about cutting it off. Just a fantasy. It’s the hand that’s crazy, not me.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What? If it doesn’t like an ultrasound wand, how’s it going to react to a needle?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Can you get music into this room?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think you’re using your relationship with Cuddy as a replacement for drugs. You should be in more pain so soon into detoxing, but your body’s full of romantic endorphins. And on top of that, you create this distraction of looking for proof.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Think I should stop and let the pain flood back?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Cuddy is not a Vicodin substitute.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Quite the opposite.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You have to wait for her to be ready.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great advice. You pretend that I’m gonna do that.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’ve made two major changes in your life. Not a time anyone’s judgment is at its best.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Didn’t you use to argue that my judgment would be better off drugs? Admit it. You’re curious why I want to make her angry.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m sure it’s convoluted, wrong and stupid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re dying to know what I found in her coffee cup.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oxytocin.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oxytocin. The chemical involved in emotional bonding.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Her lips say “no,” her hormones say “Oh, my God, yes. More!”

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. For you to know her levels were elevated, you’d need a baseline to compare them with.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I paid the guy in the gym to retrieve one of her water bottles from the trash.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Love inspires us to greatness.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, I need to make her lose her temper. Which breaks her delusion. Which demonstrates to me and to her that there’s something underneath this facade.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And then what happens? She admits everything and falls into your arms?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s outcome one. Outcome two is she kills me. I think it’s 50/50 right now.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought you’d say that.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re committing yourself to something. To someone. I mean it’s childish in a way but ultimately great. Assuming… Are you absolutely sure you want this to succeed?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why is an old guy standing in my doorway?

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: Eugene Schwartz. Eugene Schwartz. Dr. Cuddy asked me to come up here from the clinic. She says you’re seeing patients in your office. It’s still free, though, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She sent him. That’s gotta mean something.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’ll go get my decoder ring.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: I squawk. Like a parrot. Cawwww. No. That’s not it. It started a few months ago. I was doing some woodworking in my garage. I was trying to make a chair. Was it the chair? Anyway, all of a sudden, from nowhere, this strange noise comes bursting out of my mouth. Caw, caw. Tough to fake that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nice pants.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: My wife, Mona, thinks I’m busting her chops. It’s ruining my marriage. Where are we going?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So, your left hand would rather play air guitar than give me a hard time?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: It’d rather play air guitar than tie shoes, eat dinner…

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You’re right hand’s playing too.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: I don’t wanna discourage it.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Splinter hemorrhages under his fingernails.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: What’s that?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: BP and O2 sats are dropping!

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Need a bag of B-negative in here!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So much for sarcoidosis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Points to a clotting issue. Clots would explain all his symptoms. Why aren’t we in the office?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m tired of clinic duty. There’s only one thing that could cause squawking, right?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Yeah. We gave him heparin and did an echo of his heart to see if it was throwing clots, but —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: More air guitar?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The heart’s fine. We wanted to test for Factor V Leiden, Protein C, Protein S but the hand got tired of cooperating. We finally knocked him out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And all the tests came up negative anyway, or you would have opened by telling me your brilliant diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He apologized for being sweaty, said it had always been an issue but what if it’s a symptom? There are cancers that can cause night sweats and can lead to clots — lymphoma…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or pancreatic cancer. Go scan his pancreas. And try Led Zeppelin.

utterance.speaker: Man A
utterance.content: We’ve always remembered what this hospital did for Leo when his appendix burst.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Still, a check this size…

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: Sorry to interrupt. Here’s my poo. Dr. House said to bring it over and leave it with you as soon as I could. I don’t know if you people have an official term for it —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Stool sample.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: Ah, yes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thank you. I’ll take care of it.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: It’s hard to rush these things. Even if you’ve eaten a lot of broccoli.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Annie called. She’s not coming back.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: This is not the best time.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Look, you said the heparin would keep new clots from forming.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Maybe. But something’s obviously causing the clots.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If you have pancreatic cancer —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We’re not trying to scare you, but even in its early stages the fatality rate…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You walk out of here —

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Stop! Look, I’d ask you to put yourself in my place, but nobody can put themselves in my place. Did she find somebody new? Was I not being attentive enough? No. She’s just tired of being insulted by a limb. She said that my feelings toward her were mixed. Well, my feelings aren’t mixed.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You’re not going anywhere unless you wanna go naked. Your right brain knows you need to stay.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: My right brain’s an ass.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Got a minute?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s something wrong with this cup.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I need someone to bounce ideas off of. Someone to be my whiteboard. That’s how you taught me to work. I have three choices. First, I can accept it’s over, pretend we don’t work in the same hospital, have selective visual impairment when we pass each other in the hall. Second, I can accept it’s over and leave —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or you could try making him angry. Standard choice number three.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Third, I can talk to him. But it’s not like I have any new fact that I can present and Chase has this romantic view of love that reality can’t compete with.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know how you could succeed.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just say the magic words: “I will destroy my husband’s sperm.” Oh, you mean succeed without doing that. Probably not.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I have doubts. Normal doubts. It’s not wrong to prepare for bad things to happen even if you don’t expect them to. I don’t expect my condo to burn down, but I have fire insurance.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Patient’s girlfriend left him, now he wants to leave us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If your condo rules don’t let you buy insurance, would you go homeless?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: His room is this way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What, do you think I can fix this? We need to offer this guy something he can only get if he stays in the hospital — relationship counseling.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I don’t know if his girlfriend’s —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I mean his two hemispheres. That’s the breakfast of relationships — the most important one of the day. We need your special skills.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Uh, is the guy out there? The guy that’s gonna make my right brain work?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, for… What do you think your right brain wants?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: How should I know? It’s crazy. It does things I would never do.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Duct of Wirsung‘s slightly enlarged but within normal parameters.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Say something.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s mute. It can’t communicate with you. Maybe you should try communicating with it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: “Talk to her.” The well isn’t deep, is it?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re the dominant half. You make all the decisions. The right side has no control over anything. It must be… frustrating.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No masses in body or tail segments.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: I can’t communicate with it. That’s the whole —

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: When you decide to go and get groceries, what do you do?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: What do you mean? I put on my jacket and I go to the store.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your right brain has no idea why you’re suddenly getting up and putting on your jacket. It just gets dragged along. Next time, try saying it out loud.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Just say to the empty air “Hey, I think I’ll go to the store because we’re out of peanut butter”? How much did they teach you about people like me when you were learning to be a therapist?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m an oncologist.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your right brain likes what he’s saying. Hasn’t moved the entire scan.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Hasn’t gotten us anything, though. Scan’s clean. It’s not pancreatic cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Clotting could be a problem well before a solid tumor forms. It can still be pancreatic.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yes, but if you want a diagnosis backed by actual evidence, we should probably look at other cancers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: House.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: I just squawked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: Eugene Schwartz, your patient from yesterday. I just squawked. I was buying some flowers for Mona. It happened when I was paying the clerk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I assume Dr. Cuddy gave you this number.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: Yes! She told me to call you any time I squawked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m sorry but I’m about to lose you because I’m about to drive into a tunnel in a canyon on an airplane while hanging up the phone. I might be getting some more phone calls, so let’s make it fast.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Lymphoma —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s right, pancreatic. I know it’s pancreatic. I know there’s evidence. I know I’ve seen it. I just can’t —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Right brain, left brain issues?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If the cancer’s too small to find, let’s make it easier. Let’s open him up and paint it. There’s a new procedure using scorpion toxin and infrared paint. Paint only works on the cancer cells. Makes ‘em easier to spot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just agitating the pancreas can cause clotting. And you want to do it to a guy whose problem is clotting?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I’m right about pancreatic cancer, the only chance he’s got is finding and removing those cancer cells now.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: His brain MRI showed narrowing in the blood vessels leading up from the neck. If we do shake something loose, we could kill him.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Or one of him. Clot in his brain could kill one of them without affecting the other.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He might actually be okay with that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How long’s it gonna take?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Assuming he doesn’t crash… a few minutes.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey. You and Cameron. I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll be right back.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t wanna be homeless.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Okay. You can stay in the condo. I’ll find some other —

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s not what I mean. I wanna marry you. I got the forms to destroy the sperm.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You sure?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I wanna hug you but then I’d have to rescrub.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: BP’s dropping.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No sign of cancer. BP’s 90 over 60.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You never answered my question.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax. Our friendship is not doomed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Thank God. But my question was do you really want Cuddy or is this just another challenge?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re worried that once I’m in a relationship, you and me’ll be over.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hey, I’m actually for this. I think this is great. But if you’re serious and you don’t treat it seriously, then you will get hurt. And, if you don’t accept that, then accept that she will get hurt.

utterance.speaker: Stripper
utterance.content: I was told it was your birthday.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I understand.

utterance.speaker: Stripper
utterance.content: I’m so, so sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Stripper
utterance.content: Clearly there was a mix-up.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Have a nice day.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She look angry?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If you’re standing there when she looks up here —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, no.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Systolic’s 80.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Gotta finish this suture before I can get out.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Give him a dopamine drip.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You weren’t looking up at the right time.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Get to your point. We’re a little busy here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The clots aren’t from cancer. They’re coming from his heart.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We echoed the heart. No clots.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not while we were looking. Didn’t I open with that? The clots were caused by an arrhythmia.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No arrhythmia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not while we were looking! Intermittent arrhythmia. This guy pulls our equipment off at the slightest provocation. We’d have to be watching at the exact moment it happened. Which I’m guessing from the way you two are scrambling around like idiots, is right now. Yes. I’m saying do a transesophageal echo.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We have to get his BP stable.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely. Right after the echo.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Systolic’s 70.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The heart looked healthy at the last echo and an arrhythmia wouldn’t cause clots in a healthy ventricle. So start with the left atrial appendage.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Wow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yep. I did it again. Now get this poor guy’s BP under control and seal off the appendage. Then all we have to do is find out what damaged his heart before it goes after something he really needs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what damages a healthy 20-year-old heart enough to make it send out clots like it’s bombing Dresden?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Rhabdo?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Would have fried his kidneys, too. What about Graves?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Thyroid function tests were normal.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Cushing’s. Cortisol overproduction could interfere with heart rhythm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Run a dexamethasone suppression test.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Annie.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: You hit me.

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: I know. I’m so sorry but… It wasn’t me.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: I know you would never have done that if you were in control of yourself but…

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: But you came back.

utterance.speaker: Annie
utterance.content: To talk with your doctors. I’ve been going over and over what happened and I had this thought out of nowhere. Ever since I’ve known Scott I’ve seen his left hand throw things but always sort of playfully, thinking it’s fun. But when he threw this… it was angry. And that’s when his hand slapped me, too — when I brought it to him. Could it mean something?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Deodorant shouldn’t… How often do you use it?

utterance.speaker: Scott
utterance.content: Uh, a few times a day. It’s special heavy-duty stuff. I have to send away for it.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Sprayed around a bathroom the size of a shoebox.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I’ll check the ingredients from the manufacturer.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I’ll check for any references associated with health issues.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Somebody’s grateful.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We’ll just leave the… three of you alone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why is there no lipstick on this cup? Cuddy was wearing lipstick when she drank from it. It was on my face. Why isn’t it on the cup?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why is it always reasonable in Houseland to take an emotional problem and sidestep it by turning it into a mechanical problem?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because in Houseland, and the rest of the universe, by the way, when a question presents itself, it calls for an answer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If the left brain is the interpreter of reality and the one that tells us the story of who we are, then what is your story? Do you wanna be the man with the answers, or do you wanna be the man with Cuddy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do I do?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You make her angry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You really think that was the best time to mock me?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m as surprised as you, but I think I’m serious. Communication can’t start unless you both —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve been trying to make her angry for —

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, you haven’t. Come on! Poo? Strippers? It’s routine stuff. You’ve been pulling your punches. You’re scared. You should be. Now go terrorize her.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You don’t wanna destroy it, do you?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I said I was gonna do it. I’ll do it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: But you don’t want to.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I want to be with you. Maybe I’m not comfortable with it, but —

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Let’s say it’s our fifth anniversary. Are you ready to destroy it now? Tenth. Three kids. They spend their summers in Melbourne and have annoying accents. It’s disgusting how happy we are. You ready now? You don’t have doubts. You just don’t wanna kill the only thing left of someone you loved. Don’t do it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I do have trouble giving things up. For example, I never canceled any of our wedding plans.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Attention! I have an announcement. As you go about your day, I would like you to be aware of the fact that I slept with Lisa Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is beyond ass-hood! You have the luxury of not caring about your image. I do not! I can permit a lot of crap, but an employee shouting about his sexual exploits with me — no! That is zero tolerance! So congratulations, House. I am angry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was wondering if we should move in together.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re fired.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: I wouldn’t worry about it. I think she likes you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I’m fired, I think that probably means I don’t have to see patients.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: I’m here as a squeaky wheel. I know how you doctors are. You’re busy. You get distracted. My lab results could be sitting in your in-box.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t need your labs. You have acid reflux.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: Well how could you…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Acid splashes on the vocal chords, they tense, make that squawking sound. It’s completely harmless. I’m gonna give you a prescription and you are gonna go away.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: You are a great doctor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why’d you move your belt?

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: I always move my belt. Makes me sore.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You didn’t tell me that.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: At 86, what isn’t sore? Soreness is less important than squawking. It’s the squawking that was bothering my wife.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not a potbelly. It’s a tumor. That’s why pancreatic cancer was on my mind. My brain was trying to tell me…

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: This isn’t sounding good. Pancreatic cancer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It can cause acid reflux. We should scope you.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: So it’s not good. Even for cancer, it’s not good.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No it’s not.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The deodorant has a high proportion of propylene glycol. Same stuff made a kid in Singapore develop a heart condition and, get this, seizures. Our patient may never have needed split-brain surgery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m sure he will half-appreciate the irony. Take this man to radiology. Pancreatic scan. And stay with him.

utterance.speaker: Eugene
utterance.content: Eugene Schwartz.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Whatever it is, just say it quickly.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you have more than one lipstick in the same shade? Maybe one that has a sealing agent and one that doesn’t?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How could that possibly be relevant to anything?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You really don’t think you’re just… overreacting to the other night?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine. I am overreacting. You’ve said plenty of lousy things to me before. But reaching the final straw has been a good thing because it made me realize we not only don’t have a personal relationship, we never could.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wha… You… You’re… You’ve been overreacting to something I said?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You insulted me. I walked out. It’s nothing that hasn’t happened a hundred times before.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I quit.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Great. My nanny is off the clock at 7:30 so your week off —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can go suckle the little bastard child who makes you feel good about yourself.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Screw you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, no. That — that’s not what happened. I told you that I needed you. You — You helped me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: So… This is the story you made up about who you are. It’s a nice one.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Too bad it isn’t true.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. I’m not okay.

utterance.speaker: Notes
utterance.content: For the final scene in Cuddy’s office I tried to put the descriptions of the flashbacks in the past tense and the present in the present tense. I’m sure I messed it up a few times.
